projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Arthur of Brytayn.
Â¶The hystory of the moost noble and valyaunt knyght Arthur of lytell brytayne, translated out of frensshe in to englushe by the noble Iohan bourghcher knyght lorde Barners, newly Imprynted.

div.head: Here foloweth the translatours prologue.
div.p: FOr as moche as it is delectable to all humayne nature to rede and to here these auncient noble Hystoryes of the chyualrous Feates and marcyall Prowesses of the vyctoryous Knyghtes of tymes paste whose tryumphaunt dedes yf wrytynge were not sholde be had cleue oute of remembraunce. And also bycause that ydelnesse is reputed to be the moder of al vices, wherfore somwhat in eschewynge therof and in the waye of lowli erudycyon and learnynge I Iohn Bourghchere knyght lorde Berners haue enterprysed to translate out of frensshe in to our maternal tongue a noble hystory makynge mencyon of the famous dedes of the ryght valyaunt knyght Arthur sonne and heyre to the noble duke of Brytayne and of the fayre lady Florence doughter and heyre to the myghty Emendus kynge of the noble realme of Soroloys, and of the grete trouble that they endured or they attayned to the perfourmaunce of theyr vertuous amorous desyers, for fyrste they ouercame many harde & strauÌge aduentures the whiche as to our humayne reason sholde seme to be incredible, wherfore after that I had begon this sayd processe I haue determined to haue left and gyuen vp my laboure for I thoughte it sholde haue be reputed but a folye in me to translate beseming suche a fayned mater wherin semeth to be so many vnpossybylytees, how be it than I called agayne to my remembrauÌce that I had redde and seen many a sondrye volume of dyuerse noble hystoryes wherin were contayned the redoubted dedes of the auncyent inuynsyble conquerours & of other ryght famous knightes who acheued many a straunge and wonderfull aduenture the whyche by playne letter as to our vnderstandynge sholde seme in a maner to be supernaturall, wherfore I thought that this present treatyse myght as well be reputed for trouth as some of those. And also I doubted not but that the first auctour of this boke deuysed it not with out some maner of trouthe or vertuous entent, the whiche consyderacyons and other gaue me agayne audacyte to contynue forth my fryste purpose tyll I had fynysshed this sayd boke, not presumynge that I haue reduced it in to fresshe ornate polysshed englysshe, for I knowe my selfe insuffycyent in the facondyous arte of rethoryke, nor also I am but a lerner of the language of frensshe how be it I truste my symple reason hath ledde me to the vnderstandinge of the true sentence of the mater, accordinge to the whiche I haue folowed as nere as I coude desyrynge all the reders and herers therof to take this my rude traÌslacion in gre and yf ony faute be to laye it to myn vnconnynge and derke IngnorauÌce and to mynysshe, adde, or augmet as they shall fynde cause requysyte, and in theyr so doynge I shall praye to god that after this vayne and transytory lyfe he may brynge them vnto the perdurable Ioye of heuen. Amen.

div.head: Â¶Here after foloweth the table of thys present hystorie.

list.label: Â¶The fyrste chapyter maketh mencyon of the byrth of the noble kynght Arthur sone and heyre to the duke of Brytayne. Capitulo .i.

How ye duke of brytayne delyuered his soÌe Arthur to the gouernaunce of a prudent knyght named syr Gouernar who dyde ensygne hiÌ in all goodly maners & dedes of armes so that afterward there was none lyke vnto hym. ca. ii.

Â¶How Arthur founde in the forest a noble lady wtout socour, & with her a fayre yonge mayde her doughter named Iehannet before a lytell lodge the whiche they had made of ye brauÌches of the trees And how yt Arthur was amorous of the sayd Iehannet. caplo. iii.

Â¶How Arthur caused to be delyuered to IehaÌnet & her moder the reuenues that bleoÌged to the slange or ponde of the foreste, whereby there stode a fayre goodly place of pleasure, & afterwarde Arthur dyde oftentymes resorte thyder to passe the tyme with them. cap. iiii.
How within .viii. dayes after Arthur & Gouernar went to ye stange to se ye lady & Iehannet her doughter. ca. v.
How that the duke & duches toke couÌ seyle to mary theyr son Arthur, & howe they sent theyr stewarde to the lady Luke of ostryge for to demaunde her doughter for Arthur. cap. vi.
How the sene shall demauÌded ye doughter of ostrige for Arthur of brytayne, the which request wt grete ioye was grauÌ ted him. capitulo .vii.
How yt Arthur was sore displeased for that his fader wold mary hiÌ to ye doughter of ostrige bicause it was said she was of yll gouernance. ca. viii.
Â¶How yt Arthur went to se Iehannet & declared to her how the duke his fader shold mary hiÌ whereof he was sore displesed for the loue of her. ca. ix,

How yt Arthur & Hector his cosin germayne were made knightes for the loue of Arthur, who than dyd ensure Pe â¢ ron doughter to the ladi luke of ostrige, & of ye grete tournai yt was there done at nauÌtes for the loue of arthur. ca. x.
Â¶How that Arthur wedded fayre Perron doughter to the lady Luke of ostryge. And of the protestacyon that he made before all the barony. ca. xi.
Â¶How this lady Luke of ostryge sente for Iehannet & caused her secretlye the first night to lie wt arthur bycause yt perroÌ was no mayde, to thentente that arthur shold not perceyue it ca. xii.
Â¶ How yt Iehannet who was a bed wt arthur in the stede of his wyfe PerroÌ, & or she wold suffre him to touche her she demauÌded her endowrie. ca. xiii.

Â¶How that arthur Hector, & Gouernar went erly in the morninge to se IehaÌnet at the stange, who shewed vnto ar â¢ hur all the treason of his wyfe, & how that she had layne with him all that night in stede of Perron, wherof he meruayled greatly â¢ cap. xiiii.
Â¶How ye Gouernar vaynquisshed in batayle syr AuÌsel caused hiÌ to make knowledge of this treason & coÌfe â¢ sed how yt he brought IehaÌnet fro the stange for to ly all nyght wt Arthur. ca. xv.
Â¶ How arthur demaunded liceÌce of his father and mother to go play him out of his owne countrey for he wold go seke aduentures to shewe therby his force & prowesse. capâª xvi

Â¶How the mighty kinge of Soroloys called EmeÌdus helde open courte in his realme, where as was foure puyssauÌte
kynges, who were al his subgectes, and there ye shal here of thynges ryght meruaylo â¢ s. capitulo .xvii.

Â¶ ãâã
â¢â¢ scrypcyon of the facyon and sytuacy â¢â¢ of the mount peryllous the whiche was conquered bi the prowesse of Arthur. capitulo. xviii.
Â¶How it was determyned that the quene Fenyce sholde take her chaumber in the palays besyde the castell of the porte noyre. capitulo .xix.

Â¶ How that the doughter of the myghty kynge Emendus & of Fenyce his quene â¢ is destenyed ouer the fouÌtaine in ye herber of the m â¢ unt perillous by .iiii. quenes of yt fayry, the chyefe of them was named Proserpyne, who was the moste fayrest creature of all the worlde. ca. xx.
â How ye king of valefouÌd sent his son to ye city of Sabba for to be brought vp in the coÌpany of Florence. ca. xxi.
Â¶How yt the quene Fenice mother to Florence dyed, & how she made her testameÌt gyuyng to her doughter a rynge in puttyng her therby in possessyon of the realme of blaunche toure. ca. xxii.
Â¶ How the quene Fenyce mother to Florence was nobly buryed. ca. xxiii.

How ye themperour of ynde the more demauÌded of kynge Emendus the fayre Florence his doughter in maryage. And of the answere ye kynge Emendus made to hym And also of the terme yt was taken to m â¢ ry FloreÌce, and how that maister Steuen knewe by the regarding of the planettes that their was commynge out of the west a knyght, who shoulde achiefe the aduentures of the porte noyre And how he shoulde haue and enioye the whyte shelde and the swerd and obtaine Florence in maryage, wherof she was greatly comforted, for in no wyse she loued the emperour. ca. xxiiii.

How that Arthur slewe twelue knightes, who hadde taken a waye a younge, damoysell fro her father and mother, & had tyed her to a tree, there to haue defouled her virginytye, who was saued by Arthur. capitulo .xxv.
Â¶ How that Arthur Hector & gouernar slewe .xxx. theues in a grete forest the whiche was a grete welth to all the countre, for they had pylled and wasted the countre all aboute. Capitulo .xxvi.
Â¶How that syr de la launde shewed to Arthur the occasyon why that this tourney was fyrst taken by the lord Beauten capitulo .xxvii.

Howe that Arthur had the honour in the tourney that was made at Oyen betwene the Marshall of Mirpoys & the erle of Beauieu, where as was dyuerse great kynges, erles, barons, and many other good knyghtes ryghte valyaunte, whereby Arthur gate hym great thanke and prayse and was greatly honoured of all ladyes and damoyselles there assembled. capitulo .xxviii.
How yt Arthur the second day had the honour of the tourney, & so wt hym abode the pryce of the fyelde. ca. xxix.

How that the Marshal of myrpoys for enuy that he had bicause that Arthur had the honour of the tourney and because he had beaten him downe, for he had wende hym selfe to haue ben the b â¢ st knyght of the worlde, therfore he defyed Arthur & chalenged hym to Iuste. And howe that Arthur vaynquyshed him and dyd break one of his armes and two rybbes in his sydes. capitulo .xxx.

H â¢ w that Arthur was crowned to be kyng of al the knightes of the tourney & they promysed hym fayth & trou â¢ h to serue hym in deedes of armes alwayes & in euery place where as it semed hym beste,
and the yonge kinge of Malogres dyd crowne him. ca. xxxi.

How that arthur after his crownacioÌ toke leue of the yoÌge kyng and of al the other lordes & knightes, ladies & damoyselles, who conuayed him on hys Iourney warde, and had great sorow to leue his company. ca. xxxii.

How arthur and his coÌpany ariued in the erledom of brewle marching against the land of sorolois and entred into the citie of brewle, the which was besyged bi the duke of orgouie named maiaquis bicause the erle wold not let hi haue his doughter in mariage, whereof by false treas â¢â¢ he slew the erle. ca. xxxiii.

How yt Arthur went alone to the duke of Orgoule & gaue him his answere and had hi abide no lenger for the rayre alice For he shewed him how yt he had giueÌ her to hector his co â¢â¢ n. And how that he had promised to her his head bycause he slew her father by treason, wt the which answere the duke was sore displeased so much that there was bytwene them a great batayle. ca. xxxiiii.
How Hector & Gouernar & syr Othes rode out of the Citie wel accompanied to rescow arthur, who all alone assayled the duke of Orgoule and all his armie. cap. xxxv.

Â¶ How Arthur, Hector, Gouernar, & syr Othes discomfyted Peter the cornu, broder to the duke who was comen to him wi â¢ h, iiii. C. knightes, & there this cornu was slaine, & al his people slayne & takeÌ prisoners, and howe Arthur tooke the dukes horse named assyle, the best â¢ orse as thaÌ of the worlde ca. xxxvi.
Â¶ How that arthur & his coÌpany vtterly discomficed the duke & strake of hys head, & did sende it by Gouernar to the fayre ladi Alice & to her moder as he had promysed before. ca. xxxvii.

How arthur and his company wente to the citie of orgoule for to take it by force, but the burgeyses therof br â¢â¢ ght vnto him the keys, and dyd vnto ãâã homage, and so dyd all the nobles of that countrey as vnto theyr chefe soueraine lorde. cap. xxviii
How yt arthur made his cosin Hector duke of Orgoule by the assent of all the lordes of ye countrey. ca. xxx â¢ x.
How that Arthur & Gouernar departed a souder, and of the terrible aduentures that eche of them founde or they met agayne. cap. xl.

How Gouernar after that he was departed fro Arthur fouÌd in a great forest two knightes armed who had beaten & wounded an other knight & wolde haue rauysshed his syster, and how he rescowed her and dyd vaynquysshe at her enemies. ca. xli.

How that Gouernar came to a stronge castel called the brosse, & vaynquy â¢ shed the knight that kept it. And how that afterwarde he was kept in that ca â¢ tell agaynst his wil in great dauÌger of deth tyl at the last Arthur deliue â¢ ed him as ye shal here hereaf â¢ er. ca xiii.

How yt Arthur conquered the castell of the porte noyre by his prowesse, & slew all them yt kept it, & howe after that he entred in the halles of the palays, where he was assayled of two great & horyble lyons and of a great giaunt, and how he ouercame them al with great payne, & acheued all the meruaylous adueÌtures of the castel, the whiche are ryght wonderous to reherse. ca. x â¢ iii

How arthur after yt he had acheued ye adueÌtures of the palays & delyuered the prysoners, & after how yt he acheued the aduenture yt was in the galery going in
to the gardin of the mouÌt perillous, & bi his myght with a great barre bet down ii. massyue ymages of coper eche of theÌ holding & flayle yt was of such wight yt x. men migh â¢ scant lift one of them fro the erth, wherwt they we â¢ e euer betinge wyth great strokes made by enchauÌtement, to thentent that none sholde passe into the ga â¢ dins of the mouÌt perillous, & so thaÌ fayled and ended al the enchauÌtmaentes of that place. cap. x â¢ iiii.
Â¶ How mayster Steuen wente with arthur in the palays wtin the castell to the enten â¢ to se the wonderful adueÌtures yt arthur had there acheued. ca. xlv.

Â¶How proserpyne quene of the fayry about mydnight appered to Arthur with great lyght of torches, and how that she shewed him that wtin the mouÌt perilous there was the white shelde and the good swerde enchauÌted called â¢ larence, & how that he should haue them with much honour if his hert durst serue hym. And how the next day mayster Steuen ledde Arthur into ye herber where as the white shelde was, the which could neuer be remeued fro the tree wheron it haÌged, and how that Arthur toke it at his ease & cla
â¢ ence the swerde also the whiche coulde neuer before that time be drawen out of the shethe, nor it wold helpe no body but al only Arthur who drew it out lyghtly, & after that it did him much helpe as ye shal here after. ca. xlvi.
Â¶How mayster Steuen shewed arthur how ye Gouernar â¢ is knight was in the castel of brosse, & how yt the custome of ye castel was fyrst begon. ca. xlvii.

How that arthur whan he was departed fro the porte noyre for to go to delyuer Gouernar out of the castell of the brosse & also for to fyght with the monster â¢
âª he founde in a fayre medow the neuew of the duke of bygor accompanied with .xiii. other knightes, who assayled hym right fyersly, but he defended hym self so valiauÌtlye yt he slew .iii. of them & wounded so the dukes neuew that he was fayne to be caried away in an horse litter. cap xlviii.

Â¶How that arthur fought wt the monster, the most foulest & horrible fygure that euer was seen with mannes eyen & so vainquished him by his valiauÌt prowesse, & strake of his head & did sende it to the fayre Florence ca. xlix.

Â¶ How that the kyng Emendus sent a knight named Brisebat accompanyed with a thousand men of warre to thentent that he and hys company shold go fight with the monster, and how the said knight ariued at the monsters pytte the same season whyle that Arthur and the monster were fighting together, & there he and al hys company dyd se how that Arthur slew the monster without helpe cap. l.

Â¶How syr Isembartes cosyn enbusshed hym in a great forest wyth a great multitude of meÌ of warre to thentent to slea Arthur by treasoÌ, & were Arthur did wt hys handes such dedes yt in a maner it was incredyble. And how that Gouernar & Brysebar were taken prysoners and led forth to a toure, & there Arthur slew of hys enemyes .v. hondred & mouÌ ted into the toure, & so rescowed the prysone â¢ s in the spite of al the town & there wanne the palays. ca. li.

Â¶ How Arthur & hys coÌpany were besyged in ye palays by the duke of bigor, but thanked be god they escaped by the subtil arte of mast â¢ r SteueÌ clerke to the fayre Florence of Soroloys. ca. lii.

Â¶ How mayster Steuen by the vertu of hys arte o â¢ nigromaÌcy delyuered arthur
& his coÌpany fro peryl & dauÌger of yt duk of bygor & his neuewe. cap, liii.

Â¶ How the neuewe of Brysebar aryued at the courte of the mighty king Emendus with the head of the monster, & dyd salute the kynge and also the Emperour of ynde who was styll in the courte attendynge that the kyng shoulde giue him in maryage his doughter the fayre florence and to her the head of the monster was pres â¢ nted from Arthur, and â¢ hewed her how that al onely by his noble prowesse he had slayne the terryble monster of the brosse. capitulo. liiii.

â How that Arthur & mayster Steuen wente to the garden pertaynynge to the palays of the portenoyre; and entred in to the ryche pauylion where as ye ymage was holdynge in her handes the chaplet the which she dyd set on Arthurs head â¢ in sygnificacion how that he shold haue the fayre Florence to whome the ymage was resemblable, for there was non that sholde haue Florence in maryage wyth out he shold dye an euell death, withoute it were he that the ymage dyd gyue vnto the sayd chaplet. ca. lv.
Â¶ How that Arthur slewe and dyscomfyted .xv. knyghtes ryghte myghty and puyssaunt, who were com to assayl his hoost, who was called the squyer of the plashes. capitulo .lvi.

Â¶How the gret vilayn broughte Arthur where as he fought with a greate & a terryble lyon, but fynally Arthur slew him And how after he fought with a gret gyauntesse and an horryle gyaunte, and by his prowesse he conquered them bothe, & after that fought with a gret gryffon, & this was the begynnynge of the aduentures of the toure tenebrous, wherein ye shal here many terryble and meruaylous thinges, the which were all achyeued by the onely prowesse of the valyaunte Arthur. capitulo .lvii.

Â¶ How on the next mornyng the vylayn brought Arthur to an other aduenture nye to the toure tenebrous, whe â¢ e as he was fyrst assailed wt terrible monstrous byrdes and grete gryffon â¢ wi â¢ hout nombre, and after that he was assayled with xxiiii. knyghtes, and how he by hys prowesse slewe theym all. And also he bette downe the grete machomet of bras out of the whiche there yssued suche a wynd that it tourned aboute greate mylstones lyke pouder, and also how that he entred into the castell tenebrous, and quenched the fyre which was the cause of the gret deckenes the whyche contayned the cyrcuyte of .v. leges compasse as ye shal h â¢â¢ e afterwarde. ca. lviii.
Â¶ How arthur bette downe the gret machomet syttynge in the vessell of brasse, & therby the wynde ceased. ca. lix
Â¶How that Arthur entred into the toure tenebrous, and howe he there quenched the fyre, wherby all the terryble enchantement ceased. ca. lx.

Â¶How after yt Brysebar & mayster SteueÌ were departed fro Arthur fro the porte noyre they aryued at cornyle where as kynge emendus was, and in his company the emperour of ynde, & his other â¢ in kynges holdynge the same tyme a grete sumptuous open courte, & there mayster Steuen & Brysebar recounted to theym all in open audyeÌce the noble â¢ hyualry of Arthur, & this same meane season there came into the courte a knyght all armed and brought tydynges to the kyng how al the aduentures of the toure tenebrous were acheued by the only prowes of one noble knyght. ca. lxi

Â¶ How the Emperour was aferde leaste Florence sholde cast her loue on Arthur,
wherfore the demaunded of the kyng her father to haue her in maryage wtout any lenger delaye, wherwith the kyng was contente, but Florence wolde not agree therto, wherwith the king her fader was with her ryght sore dyspleased as ye shal here afterwarde. ca. lxii.
How Florence whan she knewe yt maister SteueÌ was come to ye court she was right glad, & how yt he by his policy gate her lenger respyte, yt was tyll bartilmew tyde next after. ca. lxiii.
How that Arthur was receiued of the fayre lady Margarete into the cytye of Argence. capi. lxiiii,
How that the next day the maister answered for the lady, and Arthur toke her quarell in hande against ye du â¢ es neuew syr Asembarte, cap, lxv,

How the same season whyle the kyng of orqueney & al these other noble people were at dyner in great ioye and myrthe there came in a messeÌger fro the wouÌded knyght to Arthur desyryng hym to come & helpe him or elles he wolde wyte him of his death, wherwith al the court was sore troubled, & seased all theyr Ioye for the loue of Arthur, for incontynent he departed fro the court & went forth wt the messenger, & how yt al the court fered greatly Arthur for that enterprise, for there was neuer none yt euer returned againe aliue fro that aduenture, cap, lxvi

How that Gou â¢ nar in serching of Arthur had the honour of a tourney, yt was made by the erle of the yle perdue, & there Gouenar was amorous of the countesse And how yt the erle charged the couÌtesse yt she shuld not speke to gouenar, wherof euyll came to hym, for the nexte day Gouenar dydde beate hym well in the tourney, and laye al night after with the couÌ tesse his wyfe, cap, lxvii,
How that Gouenar dyd beate downe at the tourney the erle of the yle perdue, capitulo, lxviii,

How that after Arthur was departed fro Argentou to go to the castell of hurte byse to the wounded knyght who had sent or hym, in his waye at the last he fouÌde at the entrynge of a fayre forest three ladyes of ryght excellent beautye of whom the chefe was called Proserpyn quene of the fayry who greatly desyred Arthur of his loue, but in no wyse he woulde agre therto, & there â¢ he lost his varlet that was his guid, wherfore it behoued him to tary there all ye nyght â¢ for it is darke & wyste not whether to go, cap, lxix

How Arthur conquered the castell of hu â¢ tebyse the mooste stronge place of the world nexte to the porte noyre, where as was the damoysell by whom the wouÌded knyght was hurte & there Arthur dydde soo moche by his prowesse that the sayd knyght recouered helth ca, lxx,

How that Arthur whan he was departed fro the quene Proserpyne it fortuned hym to take his lodgynge wt the neuewe of syr Isembarte, who take Arthur and locked hym fast in a toure to thentent to haue slayne hym by nyght, but there Arthur dyd so valyauntly that he brake out of the toure and slewe the knyght and al his people, capi. lxxi,

How that Gouernar in serching of Arthur by adueÌture he passed for by ye same Castell where as Arthur had slayne the lord therof, & there he was assayled of the frendes of the sayde knyght, & there dyd so valiauntly that he slewe the most part of them, cap, lxxii.

How that Arthur founde, xl, knightes who had taken a damoysell the whiche they founde in a forest, & they wold haue rauysshed her, & there Arthur rescowed
her and slewe all the .xl. knightes who wolde haue pylled & robbed the ladyes castell and haue slayne all that had ben within. cap. lxxiii.

Â¶How that mayster Steuen departed fro the porte noyre to go to the tournaye at Corni â¢ e and toke with him the noble Florence riche pauilion, wherein was the ymage with the chaplet who resembled in all thing vnto the lady Florence the most fayre creature that was as thaÌ in all the worlde. ca. lxxiiii.

Â¶ How syr Rowland of Bygor apeched Arthur of treason bycause yt he had slain his cosin at Argence, & so defyed hym at the vt â¢ raunce, but Arthur at the fyrste stroke draue him downe horse & al to the e â¢ ch, & brake one of his armes & two ribbes, wherof Florence was right ioyous and specially whaÌ she saw her louer Arthur whome she neuer saw before. And how after syr Rowlandes seruauÌtes assayled Arthur to haue slayne him, but he valiauÌtly defended himself & slew manie of them cap. lxxv.
Â¶Howe that duke Philip and mayster Steuen wente for to fetche Arthur to the king of Orqueney and to the fayre Florence. cap. lxxvi

Â¶How a great and a puissant knight defied Arthur bycause he sate by Florence & did pul downe a corner of her kerche â¢ e the which the winde had blowen vp, and so Arthur did Iuste with him and did cast him to the erth so rudely that he was not able to leye on horsebacke. v. monethes after. ca. lxxvii.

Â¶ How Florence & Arthur spake togiat good leyser at the ende of the forest, & there promised to loue eche other, & there the quene Prosepyne appered to them & shewed to Florence howe that Arthur loued her truly, & how that they shoulde haue eche other by the way of maryage but fyrst they should endure great payne and trouble cap. lxxviii.

Â¶How yt Arthur had the honour of the tournay the fyrst day the whyche was made for the fayre Florence betwene ye king Emendus and the emperour who wolde haue had Florence to his wife, on the which day arthur gat hym self great prayse amonge al the barony, in so much that euery knight was glad to be in his coÌpany, wherof the fayre Florence was right Ioyous, for she loued hym aboue al other. ca. lxxix,

Â¶ How that Florence fayned her self to be seke to the ent â¢ nt that arthur shoulde not tournay the next day, for she was infere that Arthur had ben wery bicause of the trauayle that he had en â¢ ured the fyrst day of the tournay. And howe that the emperour whan he knew yt he went to se her â¢ & so dyd her father king Emendus, and al other kinges dukes erles & barons, and all the hole chyualry. capitulo .lxxx
Â¶How that the tournay the nexte daye was deferred bycause of the dysease of Florence. Cap. lxxxi

Â¶ How the ymage in the pauilion dyd set her chaplet on Arthurs hed in the presence of themperour & of .x. other kings & of all the hole â¢ ssembly, wherwith the emperour was right sorowful bycause he thought to haue had Florence in mariage, but he fayled of his purpose, for the ymage â¢ oke no regarde nether to the emperour nor to none other there, but all only to Arthur to whoÌe frely she did giue her chaplet. ca. lxxxii

Â¶How that Proserpine qeune of the fayry who resembled to florence layde her downe in Florence bed in florence stede â¢ and she sente her vnto the Porte Noyre
with the archebysshop and al her knyghtes. caplo. lxxxiii.
How that ye lady Margarete of Argenton wt all her hole barony wente & mette Florence & receiued her in to Argence wt grete feest & Ioye. ca. lxxxiiii.

Â¶How that Proserpyne was ensured to themperour in the stede of Florence, and how that the kynge banysshed out of his countre the kyng of orqueney, & also the kynge of valefounde & mayster Steuen and Arthur. caplo. lxxxv.

Â¶How that Proserpyne quene of ye fayry was ledde to the chyrche to haue ben wedded to themperour wenynge that it had ben Florence, but whan the bysshop H â¢ d thought to haue put the weddynge rynge on her fynger, sodeynly she vanys â¢
shed awaye, soo that none wyste wheder she became, and so than they stode all abashed as though the clowdes had fallen from heuen. caplo. lxxxvi.

How that Arthur sent Gouernar to his cosin Hector duke of orgoule desy â¢ iÌge hiÌ to co â¢ e & helpe & socoure hym ayenst the emperour of ynde, & ayenst ye kyng EmeÌ dus, who wolde besyege hiÌ in the castell of the porte noyre. ca. lxxxvii.

How that Hector as he wente towarde the porte noyre to socour Arthur, he encountred one of the kynges that was comynge towarde themperour, and had in his company well to the nombre of .xviii. thousande men of warre, the whiche kynge Hector slewe & all his people, soo that there was none that euer escaped sauynge two, and soo they fledde awaye, and there Hector was a grete botyeâª and moche tresour and grete habouÌdaunce of vytayle the whiche was al brought in to the porte noyre. ca. lxxxviii.

How that themperour of ynde and the kynge EmeÌdus accompanyed with .viii. kynges. & wel to the nombre of .iii. C. M men of warre layde syege aboute the castell of the porte noyre where as florence and Arthur were, wherof yll tourned to themperour, for there he loste thre of his kynges and well an hondred thousande of his men. caplo. xxxix.
How Phylyp duke of sabary and mayster Steuen sone to the kynge of valefouÌ de were made knyghtes, and of the dyscomfyture that Arthur made on themperour, caplo. lxxxx.

How that themperour spake with the quene Proserpyne wenynge to hym that it had ben the fayre lady Florence, but h â¢ was deceyued, for she dyde set a grete discorde bytwene hiÌ & the kynge Emendus as ye shal here after. ca. lxxxxi.

How that after themperour was thus departed in dyspleasure and had defye â¢ the kynge with mortall warre the nexte nyghte folowynge by the subtyll arte of mayster Steuen all ye kynges hoost was brought euery man faste a slepe, & in the meane tyme the mayster and fyue other knyghtes with hym bare ye kyng Emendus fast a slepe as he laye, bedde and all vp in to the palays of the Castell of the porte noyre. ca. lxxxxii.
How that kynge Emendus whan that he awoke forgaue all his yl wyll to Florence his doughter, and dyde put all the gouernynge of his realme in to her handes. capitulo. lxxxxiii.

Â¶How that Arthur demaunded congye and lycence of kynge Emendus fader to his lady Florence to departe in to Brytayne to se the duke of Brytayne his fader and the duchesse his moder, the whiche lycence they gaue hym with moche payne, & FloreÌce was in grete sorowe for his departynge. ca lxxxxiiii.

How Arthur in the waye as he went â¢
to brytaine he aryued in a fayre medowe that was IoyniÌge to the towne of Lion sur le rone, & there he fouÌde the kynge of malogre accompaiÌed wt diuerse erles & other barones, and thei had there cryed a grete tournai, & there Arthur & his company were frendly receyued & had grete there bothe of the kynge & of al other lordes & knightes. ca. lxxxxv.

Â¶How that Arthur & Hector his cosyn with al theyr company ariued at Blois & how the erle of Bloys father to hector & the countesse his mother, & al the hole barony of the realme mette them on the way and receiued them with great ioye, for they had ben before in great fere yâ¢ arthur theyr neuew & Hector theyr son had ben dead. ca. lxxxxv â¢ .

How arthur aryued in Britayne and how the duke his father & al his chyualry met & receyued arthur with great honour & triumphe, & how yt the duchesse his mother sowned for Ioye whan she saw her sonne arthur, & in likewyse did Iehannet his olde loue, wherof the maister & Philip had great fere l â¢ est yt IehaÌ net should draw, away arthurs harte fro FloreÌce bycause of the great loue yt they sawe betwene the. ca. lxxxxvii

How after that arthur was departed fro kyng Emendus & Florence to go se his frendes, Florence than departed fro the porte noyre & the quene of orqueney & the lady Margaret of Argenton with her and went to sporte her in her owne realme and castell of clere toure, where as the emperour came and besyeged her for she was ware therof he & his company were inide round aboute the town and they were to the nombre of two hondred thousand, what of emperiens and of sarasins. ca. lxxx â¢ viii.

How that Arthur was right sorowful bycause that his horse dyd stomble vnder hym, and how the mayster shewed hym how that FloreÌce was besieged by themperour in her castel of the clere toure, wherof arthur was in great fere & trouble. cap. lxxxxix

How that Arthur and the mayster, Hector, Gouernar, and syr Brysebar entred into the clere toure where as Florence was besyeged, & they .v. discoÌfited a puyssaunt king sarasin who was called ye sowdan, who was come thider to helpe the emperour, and there were al the sarasyns and turkes slayne. ca. c
How that trewse was taken for a moneth bytwene the emperour and arthur cap. c. i.

How that the yonge kinge of malogre and of the duke of Brytayne, wt diuerse other erles and barons, and accoÌpanied with a great army of men of warre aryued at the clere toure, to the entent to socour Florence and Arthur who were besyeged by themperour, who had nye enraged out of his wytte whan he knewe that they were come into that countrey Cap. c. ii.
How that kyng Ionas all alone came to the castel of the clere toure, and there dyd his message fro themperour of ynde the more. cap. c. iii.

How that themperour and kynge Ionas accompanied with fyfty thousande men of warre came to the clere tour for to haue made assaute therto, & than they found the gate open and entred bothe in to the town and in to the castel, for they thought verely that al the frensshe men had bene fledde, but they were deceyued for than the frensshe men lepte out from theyr enbusshementes and shee faste the gates, & there slewe kyng Ionas & al the fyfty thousande, so yt none escaped aliue
but one and the emperour who was token prysoner. ca. c. iiii.

Â¶How Gouernar went in to the realme of Soroloys to the â¢â¢ ent to gyue knowlege to kynge Emendus how ye themperour had besyeged his doughter Florence in her castell of clere toure desyrynge hym to haste his hoost to rescowe her at that tyme. capitulo c, v.
How that Arthur accompanyed wt the frensshe men dyscoÌfyted kyng Florypes broder to themperour & slewe all them yt were in his company. ca. c. vi.
Â¶How mayster Steuen by his arte and connynge caused themperyens to goo a wronge waye from Arthur, & so encountred the myghti kynge Emendus and al his hoost. ca. c. vii.
Â¶How that themperour dyed in pryson for sorowe whan that he knewe that his kynges and people were al slayne & dyscomfyted. ca. c. viii.
Â¶How that kyng Emendus came to ye blaunche tour with al his noble company to ye buryenge of themperour and of the other .iiii. kynges. ca. c. ix.

Â¶How after ye dyscomfyture of themperour & al his people ye kyng gaue licence to all his hoost to departe euery man home, & went hymselfe to Argence there to make the weddynge bytwene Arthur & Florence, & how that Florence wente to the porte noyre to make chere to the duchesse of britayne & to the other ladyes & to brynge theym to Argence to her fader kynge Emendus. ca. c. x.

Â¶How FloreÌce bycause of the doubte yt she had leest yâ¢ Iehannet sholde take fro he â¢ Arthu â¢ she gaue her to Gouernar, & gaue them the realme of mormal, & caused them to be ensured togyder the same houre, and also the same tyme she caused The ladye Margarete to be ensured to mayster Steuen. cap. c. xi.

How Arthur wedded the fayre Florence doughter to the mighty king Emendus with great honour & triumphe, & kynge Gouernar wedded the fayre Iehannet, and mayster Steuen wedded the fayre Margaret of Argenton all in one daye and one houre, ca. c. xii

How the frensshe knightes, and those of Soroloys, of Argence, of Orqueney, of Mormall, of Ismaelite, of UalefouÌde and of Sabary did tornay togeder wherof Arthur and gouernar had the honour ca. c. xiii.

How that after the mariage of Arthur the barons and ladies of Fraunce retorned into theyr owne countreys, excepte kyng Alexander whome kynge Emendus kepte styll and made vnto hym gret chere, and he taried there so longe tyll ye Florence was delyued of a fayre sonne who kinge Alexander helde on the font cap. c. xiiii.

How king Alexander returned into his countrey and ledde wyth hym Arthur, Gouernar, Hector, and mayster Steuen and taried in brytayne so longe tyll Florence sent for Arthur bycause that her father kynge Emendus was departed out of this life, wherfore she made great lamentacion. ca. c, xv.
How that arthur was sent for bycause of the dethe of kyng EmeÌdus, and how that he was crowned kynge of Soroloys. cap. c. xvi.
Here is deuysed how long that the noble arthur liued and how that he was buried. ca. c. xvii.

div.trailer: Â¶Thus endeth the table of this present hystory.

div.head: Â¶The fyrste Chapyter maketh mencyon of the byrth of the noble knyght Arthur sonne and heyre to the duke of Brytayne. Capitulo. .1.
div.p: AFter the death of good kynge Arthur who was ryght noble â¢ nd gentyll, specyally in cherys â¢ hynge and enhaunsynge of nobylnesse, and mayntaynyng of the chyualrous knyghtes of the worlde. As was Gawyn and Lancelotte and many other noble kng â¢ htes as it is more plainly conteyned in dyuers auncyent cronycles. It is of trouth that in tho dayes in Brytayne there was a duke ryghte prudente & aboue all other ryghte vertuous, ryche and puyssaunte bothe of hauyour and frendes, who was come and extraughte of the noble hygh lygnage of the valyauÌt knyght lauÌcelot du lake who was in his dayes of right hyght & noble prowesse as it is more at large comprised in the bokes makynge mencyon of his chyualrye. This Duke had to name Iohan and was so endued wyth sappence yt the kynge who as than gouerned all Fraunce loued and honoured hym aboue all other in soo moche it was sayde where so euer he wente beholde yonder is the wyse man of britaine, he was sworne of the kynges preuye and streayte counsayle so that the kynge was onely gouerned by his noble aduise because of the gret â¢â¢ ou the and stedfastnesse yt was euer fouÌde in hym, this duke hadd a ryghte noble lady to his wyfe of good & holy life who was doughter to the erle of Leycester in Englande, & they loued togyder ryght feruently by cordyall loue al theyr lyfe, and in accomplyshing betwene them the werkes of maryage ordeyned by nature fynaltye it pleased the good Lorde to sende theym a fayre sonne, who in the remembraunce of good kyng Arthur and of his hye renowne was named Arthur. This chylde was goodly & of ful greate beaute For afterward he grew to be the mooste fayre creature that than was founde in all crystendome and the dukes & duches loued hym so well that they entended to nothynge but all onely to the prouffyte of theyr chylde, and specyally to enhaunce his honour and rych â¢ sse.

div.head: Â¶How the duke of brytayne delyuered his sonne Arthur to the gouernaunce of a prudent knyghte named syr Gouernar who dyd ensigne him in all goodlye maners & dedes of armes, so that afterwarde there was non lyke vnto him. Ca. ii.
div.p:
ANd whaÌ this chyld Arthur was nyne yere of age than the Duke his fader delyuered him to be kepte vnder the gouernaunce of a noble & a gentyl mayster named Gouernar who was
ryght prudent, puyssauÌt & hardy, vertuous â¢ vygorous of bodye & well proued, who amonge other thynges dydde teach this noble chylde Arthur the play of the chesse & tables so yt non was in coÌninge lyke vnto him. And whaÌ he was of .xx. yere than his mayster taught hym the man â¢ re of skyrmyshe so that wtin a lytle season ther was none able to be coÌpared wt hym. Thus amended this chylde frome daye to daye & grew so goodly yt in al the worlde there was none sene lyke him nether so fayre â¢ so gracyous ne so cou reyse in so muche yt the kynge of Fraunce desyred ofteÌtymes yt he sholde haue be noryshed & brought vp wyth his one chyldren. How be it ye duchesse his moder coude in no wyse suffer it ne scant to let him be oute of her presence neuer a day she loued him so enterly. So longe thys chyld soiourned wt his moder yt it was gretlye noyful to his hert, in so moche that therby he became ryght pensyfe â¢ sore troubled in his mind. So that gouernar hys mayster demaunded of hiÌ what was the cause of his sorowe. In good fayth mayster sayd Arthur this long soiorning and abyding at home greatly noyeth me, for I wolde gladly go and play me in yoÌder fayre forest. And to hunt and chase after a grete harte. For it hath ben now a grete season sythe I went ony where foorthe. Se â¢ t â¢ ynly sayde gouerner fayre Arthur it pleaseth me ryght wel your noble miÌd. There go to my ford pour fader and desyre hys lyceÌce that ye may go chase in ye forest. Th â¢ n arthur went forth to yâ¢ duk his fader and demaunded of hym lycence whaÌ the duke hard this tydyng and wyl of his son he had grete ioy & ryght swete dyd grauÌte hym his request & commaunded & desyred Gouernar that he shold take good hede to hym & not suffre hym to â¢ enne ne to folowe to faste after his dysport. Gouernar answered that he wolde take good hede to him. Than arthur caused ye huÌters to be warned & to make redy his greyhouÌdes, houndes & other raches for he wo â¢ de go the nexte daye be tymes to chase in the forest. And the nexte mornynge Arthur & Gouernar mouÌted on theyr horses wt grete Ioye & .x. other gentylmen to kepe them company. And arthur was mounted on a grete courser his hat hangynge on his backe by a lace of sylke, his bonet on his head & the hunters wente before ledinge his greyhoundes and houndes. Thus they ryde forthe toward the forest in grete ioye.

div.head: Â¶How arthur founde in the forest a noble lady wtout socour, and wt her a fayre yonge mayde, her doughter named Iehannet before a lytle lodge the whyche they had made of ye brauÌches of the trees, and how that arthur was amorus of the sayd Iehannet. Cap. iii.
div.p:
IN this tyme there was in the real me of desert a knyght of grete power and right riche of hauiour and frendes, and he was Lord of a castell called the toure. This knyght was named Vyciers and was of such vertue that he douted nothiÌge .x. knyghtes armed, and was of so valiaÌt corage that sin the time that he coude fyrst beare armes he was neuer but there as he knew where as the fayte of armes were occupyed, and employed hiÌselfe euer in iustes and tornayes and in dedes of armes and dyd so to be alowed yt there was no spekiÌge of him but that he was the noblest knight of the world, but finally he led so his life that he speÌded and wastest his goodes so largely to theÌteÌr to get hym laude and prayse that at the end he became therby very port and thaÌ was
faynt to fell and to make shyfte of all yâ¢ he had both of his owne & of the good lady his wyfe. And so dyed in grete pouerte. And whan he was buryed suche persones as he was detter vnto, toke all the londes & goodes that perteyned other to hym or to the lady his wyfe, so yâ¢ there by the good lady his wife fledde & departed pryuely out of ye couÌtree, so yâ¢ non of her frendes wyste where she was become, for she thoughte she hadde rather to lyue poorely in a straunge countrye ferre fro her freÌdes & aqueyntaunce thaÌ to endure pouerte in her owne countrye where she had ben nobly broughte vp in before. So this lady went & her doughter with her, who was of the age of .xiiii yeare ryght beautefull, how be it she was porely arayed & had to name I â¢ hannet. And they trauayled so loÌge by theyr Iorneys yâ¢ by aduenture they came in to the forest where Arthur & Gouernar were vsed to chase & to hunte. And in a desolate place of the forest ferre from ony hye way ther these two ladyes dyd reste them and made theym a lodge to abyde in of boughes and of suche thinges as they coude gette Thus they contynued the space of a moneth. And this lady went eueri day right porely to the nexte vylage for to gete suthe thinges as she & her doughter neded. And so it fortuned yt
â¢ he same day yâ¢ Arthur & gouernar departed fro the courte of his fader & was entred into the sayde foreste anone his houndes had founde a grete harte, And a noble knyghte yt was in his coÌpany named the lorde Olyuer of I â¢ y â¢ c folowed after this harte on a gret courser & all the other huÌters after hym. And this yonge Arthur began to folowe after, how be it Gou â¢ r â¢ ar toke hede yâ¢ he sholde not folowe to fast â¢ , so yâ¢ this sayde lorde Olyuer & â¢ ll other were past f â¢ rth by hym & were gon so ferre into the thicke of ye foreste yâ¢ Arthur & Gouernar had clene loste both sight and heringe of theÌ and of theyr houÌdes. And so by ges they folowed fayre and esyly after, so loÌg they folowed yâ¢ by aduenture they came to the same place where as the lodge was made for the lady & her doughter, who were bothe the same tyme syttynge wythout the lodge dore. And as soone as Arthur sawe them he lyghted downe of his hors and Gouernar wt hym. And whaÌ this lady sawe Arthur she was gretly abashed for she thought well yâ¢ he sholde be some grete man & there wt she rose and Arthur right swetely saluted her. And the lady in like wise agayne to him. And at yâ¢ tyme it was aboute thre of the clocke. And whan the ladye sawe Arthur & Gouernar dyscende from theyr horses, she remembred the state of her fader & of other geÌ
â¢â¢ lmen yâ¢ she had seene before in her owne countree where as she had be norysshed vp u â¢ wherof her herte was gretely ashamed & troubled. Than Arthur toke her by the hande & her moder also & set them do â¢ ne all togyder. Than Arthur demauÌded of the yonge mayde & sayd fayre swete damoysell what is your name. As our lord helpe me syr I am called Iehannet, IehaÌne â¢ good loue where were ye borne certayne syr I was not born in this couÌ tre. Than her moder sayd syr truely my doughter sayth sothe, for truely she was borne in the loÌd of desarte in a castel called the tour. Truly sayd Arthur to whome was she doughter. As God helpe me syr to a knyght right stronge & puyssauÌt who in his tyme loued euer dedes of armes & was acqueÌted wt many noble men How be it his fortune was such or he dyed yt he lost away & wasted both his londes and goodes and myne that was his
poore wyfe. And were broughte so ferre vnder that lytell or nothing was left vs. And after his death suche persones as he owed ony thynge to, and peraduenture some other yt he owed nothing to. They were thaÌ so importune on me that I was fayne to sel al yt I had. And whan I saw that I was so ferre broughte vnder & yt I had nothyng lefte me wherby to lyue The occasion therof caused me to steale awaye by nyghtâª for I thought I had leuer go lyke a poore woman a beggynge in a straunge countre thaÌ there where I was lady and gouernour. And therwith ryght pyteously she wept and sayd a gentyl â¢ knyghte nowe am I come in to this couÌtre a lonely accompanyed wt this yoÌg mayde my dere doughter, who was woÌt be brought vp in fayre places and ryche halles and chambres, & to lye in th â¢ bed incorteyned wyth sylke. And nowe it be ho â¢ eth her to lye on the mosse in this lodge couered wyth grene boughes. Than Arthur answered and sayde a fayre lady why dide not ye requyre youre frendes to helpe and socour you in your necessite At leste to gyue you mete & drynke & clothing. In my miÌd that had be more honorable for you thaÌ thê° desolate to come in to this strauÌge couÌtrye. As god helpe me syr sayd this lady pore folkes hath but fewe frendes, howe be it I ought to haue many, but betwene the riche & the poore there wanteth frendes, for the ryche maketh his frendes of his money & the pore is euer put out in euery place. And as to me sorowfull creature who hath bene a grete lady & moche honoured & haue had moche people vnder my obeysauÌce, thoughte grete shame to requyre ony creature in my owne cuÌtre to helpe or soccoure me. And specyally for this yonge mayde my doughter, she is come of goodly lygnage. Alas as for me I am olde and alwayes she hath serued me ryghte well, & now she is lyke wt me to lese her tyme, & ther wt she began agayne to wepe. And whan IehaÌnet sawe her moder so wepe she coude not abstayne her selfe from wepyng tenderly. And whan Arthur sawe th â¢ m so full of sorowe, he had grete pyte and sayd to the lady. My right dere lady wepe ye no more but sette youre harte in rest for fro heÌsforth I wyll be in the stede of youre olde lorde, & in all good honoure to lu â¢ e & cherish you to the best of my power. And all this whyle IehaÌnet made styll grete la â¢ entacoÌ. So there Arthur toke the yonge mayde in his armes, & ryght swetely sayd. My right dere â¢ adye & loue abandon youre herte to ioye and leue this sorowe for as god be my socoure I shall cause you haue more honoure & welth than as yet eu â¢ rcame to you, for I am and shal be your owne good loue â¢ and wyll take you in to my handes to delyuer you fro all pouertye, faythfully assuryng you to kepe the honour of you & of youre bodye as moche as youre owne p â¢ opre broder wolde or myght do.

div.head: Â¶Howe Arthur caused to be delyuered to IehaÌnet & her moder yâ¢ reuenues yt belonged to the stang or ponde of the forest wherby there stode a fayre goodly place of pleasure, and afterward Arthur, didde often tym â¢ s resorte thyder to passe the tyme with them. Capit. iiii.
div.p:
IN this season yt Arthur had this coÌmunycacioÌ wt these ladyes, ther came to theÌ the mayster forester named Pyere who was also receyuer the reuenewes of the forest & he had al ye day so â¢
ghte his mayster Arthur & by aduenture there he fouÌd him talking wt these ladyes, And incoÌtynent yt Arthur sawe hiÌ
he called hym by his name and demaundyd of hiÌ yf he had receyued at yt mawdeleyn tyde ye reuenewes of the forest, and Piers answered and said, syr I haue alredy at your coÌmauÌdement to the some of. fyue. C. pounde, well quod Arthur I coÌ mauÌde the incontynente to delyuer it to this lady & to her doughter. Also the maner place pertayning to the stang of this forest wherein thou hast dwelt to this tyme. It was so that in this staÌge or water the wylde beastes of the foreste dyd euer thyder resorte to drynke. and Ioynynge to this water there were houses and maners the which the duke had gyuen to arthur his son to playe hiÌ in the forest, and this pyers was keper thereof to Arthurs behoue. Than sayde Arthur to Pyers I delyuer to yâ¢ these .ii. ladyes. And I charge the yâ¢ truly yâ¢ kepe & honour them and briÌg them to my maner and to deliuer to them such as is apertenauÌte to so goood by ladyes as they be. And as such a man as I am haue taken into my haÌdes & kepyng. Therfore kepe theÌ well & truely. For by the fayth yt I owe to my lord my fader yf I knowe yâ¢ yu entende or ymagen agaynst this lady or her doughter any dyspleasure. I shall cause the to suffre foule death. And I warne the loke yt they lacke no thyng. Syr sayd Pyers I trust I shall so demane me yt both you & they shall be wt me contente. And so whaÌ Arthur had ben there a grete season, he toke his leue there of this lady and of her doughter. So Pyers dyd conduyte them to the said maner & bought for them abylementes & Iewelles, mete & drynke of the best yt coude be goten, & all other thynges yt was coÌuenyent for noble ladys to haue. And garnysshed euery offyce in ye house wt plate of syluer & wt all other necessary thynges. And whan Arthur and Gouernar wer departed fro these ladyes they rode after the tracke of syr Olyuer of Iryac and his companye, and at the laste they mete togyder ferre in the forest in a grete depe valey where as syr Olyuer hadde kylled thre grete hartes, and was brekynge of them. And therwith Arthur came to hym & laughed ryght swetely. Than resorted other of the hunters fro all partyes. And so there Arthur commaunded a seruaunt belongynge to the sayd Pyers to take one of these hartes & to bere it fro him to the sayd lady and to her doughter. And the seconde Arthur dyd gyue to an abbotte that was come to theym by aduenture. And the thirde he commaunded that it sholde be conueyed to the duke his fader, who hadde greate ioye therof.

div.head: Â¶How within .viii. dayes after Arthur and Gouernar wente to the stange to se the ladye and Iehannet her doughter, Capitulo. .v.
div.p:
THe eyght daye after that Arthur was come fro the foreste he rose erly in a fayre morninge and sayd to gouernar, frende lette vs go leape vppon our horses and goo se oure damoysell in the forest we two alone, gladly syr sayd Gouernar. So Arthur toke a sparhawke on his honde, and Gouernar a gerfawcon. And Arthur aparayled hym selfe all in grene silke, and his hatte auayled with a fresshe chaplet of floures on his heade. And they rode so longe that by the sonne rysynge they came to the stang and fouÌd the lady and Iehannet ready aparayled ryght nobly. For Pyers the forester had purueyed them of all thinges necessarye to suche ladyes. And as than Iehannet had dronken good wynes and taken her
sustenaunce of good metes, and had forgoteÌ all her sorowe. Wherby her beaute was newly renewed. And whan Arthur sawe her, she pleased hym moche better thaÌ she dyd whan he sawe her fyrst. And so toke her by the fayre hande and sette them downe togyder a parte. And in the meane seasoÌ the lady her moder and Gouernar were talkynge togyder. And the mornynge was very fayre & clere. And the earth all bedewed wyth clere syluer droppes. An â¢ the byrddes sange m â¢ lodiously on euery braunche so that these .ii. yonge lusty louers gretly reioysed, and had great myrthe in theyr hartes bicause of the swete season as it was metely for suche yonge people to playe & to laughe. And they loued togyder with good herte without thinkinge of vylany or shame eche to other. Than Arthur sayd to her al laughyng. My swete damoysell haue ye ony maner of louer. And halfe smiliÌg and beholdynge Arthur ryghte swetely she answered, by the fayth that I owe to you my owen dere lorde, I haue one ryghte fayre and gracyous. And where is he my swete Iehannet. By my fayth â¢ yr he is of a couÌtre wherof he is lorde. And fayre loue howe is he called, syr you not dyspleased, this that I haue sayde is suffycyent at this presente teme. How be it syr I wolde ye knew that king Arthur was a noble knyght and of grete vertu And syr I wolde my louer were so good yf he be not better all redy. But one thiÌg syr I assure you he resembleth more to you than to ony other vnder the sonne lyuynge, bothe goynge, and in comynge of bodye and all other thynges that one persone may be lykened to an other. My owne swete and fayre damoysell sayd Arthur I wolde fayne se hym. And by the fayth that ye ow to me if it be to you no vylony I praye you shewe hym to me & I promyse you faythfully I shall loue & cherysshe. hym ryght derely. And for the loue of you yf yt he wyll he shalbe one of my house, yf he be no greater of lygnage ne of rychesse than I am. My â¢ ight dere lorde sayd this damoysel huÌbly I thanke you howe be it he is no grea â¢ ter gentylman than ye be, but he thynketh well to haue as grete honour and frendes as ye haue, but as now ye may not se himâª but it may well be that here after ye shall haue knowlege of hym. And soo thus they comoned togyder of manye thinges tyll it was tyme that Arthur sholde retorne to the courte, for as than it was aboute pryme. Than Arthur toke his leue of the lady and of Iehannet. And so he and gouernar mounted on theyr horses and rode forth alwayes deuisyng of the maner of this damoysell Iehannet. And at the last Arthur sayd. Mayster howe saye you by the swetnesse of our damoysell and of the frenes of her herte, and how sagely & gracyo â¢ slye she answereth to euerye demaunde, remembrynge also her gentyll maner & noble countenaunce, her beawtefull facyon of body and of vysage. As god helpe me mayster all these thynges and manye other that saemeth of vertue to be in her, causeth that I loue her hyrtely. Syr sayde Gouernar as God helpe me all that ye saye is of trouth, how be it myne owne dere lorde take good hede to your honour a â¢ d remembre how grete a lorde ye be, both of lygnage, honoure and of frendes. And thinke how that she is but a poore gentylwoman as to your knowlege. And if ye do her ony vylony to her body, as in takynge from her that he can not render agayne, syr it were t â¢ you a grete synne. And ye ought therein to be more blamed than a nother meanes
persone. Mayster sayd arthur I praye to god neuer to helpe me yf I thynke to go aboute to dysshonoure her, but I wyll loue her & kepe her honoure faythfully in lyke case as she were myne owen proper sister without euer desyringe onye velany to her body. So they rode forthe talkyng til they came to the courte, and than went to dyner for it was by that time nere vpon two of the clocke.

div.head: Â¶How that the duke and duchesse toke counsell to mary theyr sone arthur and how they sente theyr stewarde to the lady Luke of ostrige for to demaunde her doughter for Arthur. Cap. vi
div.p: IN this wyse Arthur soiurned a great longe space so yt there was no we â¢ e but that twyse or thri â¢ e he and Gouernar wolde ryde to the stange with out any other coÌpany. And it fortuned one day he taried there lenger thaÌ he was a customed to do, wherfore he was sought all aboute by the coÌmaundement of the duke his father how be it no tydinges coude be herde of hym but that he & Gouernar were gone togider to sporte them, but no man wyste whyther. And than the duchesse sayd to the duke, syr I wote not what meaneth that our soone thus goth forth so pryuely euery day & no man can tell whyther, for he taketh none with him but Gouernar â¢ veraylye I doubte me of our chylde least that he sholde set his herte & loue on some persoÌ wherby we shold haue any velony, syr he is now of yeres sufficient to perc â¢ iue & to know the fayre perteyning to loue wherfore I wolde he were nobly maried for it is tyme, he is .xxii. yeres of age. Madame quod the duke ye haue ryght wysely sayd. And I acorde well thereto, but to whome thinke ye best it were to giue him in mariage. Syr sayd the ladye in my minde it were wel doon â¢ that we should demauÌde the fayre Perron of os â¢ ryge, & I trust my lady Luke her moder wyl be therof right glad, veryly madame sayd the duke I haue harde saye that this lady Perron hath not wyselye demeaned her selfâª but hath had greate blame for her nyse kepyng company w a knight of her countrey. And I wolde for no good yt we should demaunde such a person as hath deserued blame. A syr sayd the lady beleue not ye the reportes of them that lusteth to say y â¢ , for as god helpe me she is slaundred wrongfully. for I am sure the eis not a better maide lyuyng, wherfore they are in greate sin that reporteth ot â¢ erwyse of her. Dame sayd the duke yf it be so I am right ioyfull. Than let vs send thyder in al hast Than was called to them syr Olyuer yt was senesshall. And the duke sayde to hym, syr Olyuer I wyll ye go to ost â¢ yge to my ladye Luke & desyre of her in my b â¢ ha â¢ e Pe â¢ ron her doughter to be giueÌ in matrymony to a â¢ thur my sone. T â¢ aÌ syr Olyuer prepayred him to ride forthe And .x. other knightes in his company. and so departed and rode forth so longe that the wednesdaye after Mawdeleyntyde they came to ostryge. And whan sir Oliuer was in the great hall where as the lady Luke was acompanyed with many great barons ladyes and damoysels. He dyd right reuerently salute her and all the other lordes and barons as a messenger sent fro the duke & duchesse of Britayne. And this lady Luke right honourablye dyd receyue hym and all hys company. And demaunded what was the cause and the occasyon of their comynge.

div.head: Â¶How the senesshall demaunded the daughter of ostryge for arthur of Brytayne, the which request with great Ioy was graunted hym. Cap. vii.
div.p: THan syr Olyuer began hys proposicion & sayde. Righte hye and myg â¢ ty prynces. My lorde and ladye of brytayne hath sÃ©Ìd vs hither to publishe vnto you theyr ententes for they are ryght desyrous to haue loue and affinitie with you as it well appereth, for they haue harde suche bruce & fame of my lad â¢ Per â¢ oÌ your doughter. Wherfore thei haue sent me hither to your preseÌce to requyre you in theyr behalfe to gyue your doughter perron in mariage to arthur theyr sone, who is ryght gentyl, noble & valiaunt. Madame this is the effecte of our request. In the name of god sayde the lady luke humbly I thaÌke the duke your lorde yt it wyl please him to haue wyth vs acquentaunce, wherof I haue right g â¢ eat Ioye. And wi â¢ h a good hert I gyue freely to him my doughter Perron to be all holly at his comauÌdemeÌt Madame sayd Oliuer this dede ought greatly to be thanked. And how say you fayre lady perron, do you acorde to this mariage. Syr sayd Perron I shall euer fulfyl the pleasure of my lady my moder. Certaynly fayre lady than doo you wysely for I ensure you ye shall be coupled to him yt is both fayre and goodly. Than this ladi luke & her doughter did giue to syr Oliuer & to hys companye manye noble Iewels & other thinges. And theyr apoyntment was to be at nauntes within .viii. dayes of the middell of the next August.

div.head: Â¶How yt arthur was sore dyspleased for yt his father wold mayr hiÌ to ye doughter of ostryge bycause it was sayde she was of yll gouernaunce. Ca. viii.
div.p:
THan the senesshal toke le â¢ e of the lady Luke and of the fayre Perron and retorned into brytayne. At whiche tyme he founde the duke than risen fro diner and the duchesse with hiÌ And arthur and Gouernar were playing at the chesse, & as sone as the duke saw syr Oliuer he made him good cher â¢ and the knight right humblye saluted them and thanked them greatly for the greate loue and gyftes that the Duchesse of ostrige had done to him for their sakes, and shewed them how the lady Luke wolde be at Nauntes and bring with her Perron redy ap â¢â¢ ayled to be giuen to Ar â¢ hur aboute the middell of August next insuyng. And whaÌ Arthur herde that his fader wolde mary him he stepped forth & left his playe. And sayd what is yâ¢ right dere fader, wyll ye marie me. Ye fayre sone sayde the duke right nobly. And good fader vnto whom wyll ye gyue me, Fayre sone vnto the gentil perron of ostryge. What syr as it is noysed she hath trespased wt a nother knight â¢ set ye so litle by me that ye wyll now gyue me perroÌ who is of yl name and fame. Certainly it is not your worshyp ne honour so to do nor to none of my frendes. Therfore in no maner of wyse I wyl take her. Fayre sone sayde his moder be not displesed ne beleue no euil reportes yt is sayd by this lad â¢ it is great sin to say such thinges as cannot be proued for I am in certayne that she is a clene mayden. And therfore we wil that ye shal haue hir or els ye shal gretly dysplease my lorde your father & me
alsoâª wel madame said Arthur sith that it behoueth me to take her & that it is your pleasure y â¢â¢ I so do I am content, how be it yf she be of suche condicions as is sayd of her I shal neuer loue her. Than sayd gouernar to the duke, syr ye wyl that Arthur shall haue this damoisell. Neuerthelesse pleaseth you syr to know that if this case be found true thaÌ let Arthur leue and forsake her. And yf that she dyd neuer suche trespas thaÌ let arthur kepe her as he ought to doo hys wyfe, but how â¢ hall thys be knowen sayd the duke for where as wysedome is suche thinges are lightly done so couertly that it is harde to know, syr sayd Gouernar let it be enquyred wysely of such as to presume should know of the matter. Also let the damoysell her self be wysely examyned, & yf she be good she wyll kepe her selfe, yf she be otherwyse perauenture it will be espied. I am content with this sayd arthur. And for that time they left theyr commiÌg of that matter. Than the duke sent out his coÌmauÌ dementes to all his barons, knightes & damoysels that they sholde be al redy at nauntes bi the middes of august for thaÌ he wolde kepe open courte and make arthur his sone knight, and marye hym to the fayre Perron of ostryge. The duke also dyd write to the erle of bloys broder germayne to the duchesse his wyfe. And also sent for the erle of Aniou who was nere of kinne to the duke â¢ and also to the archebysshop of â¢ ou â¢ s desyringe them to be at n â¢ untes at the sayd daye.

div.head: Â¶How that arthur wente to se Iehannet and declared to her how ye duke his father should mary him wherof he was sore dyspleased for ye loue of her. Cap. ix
div.p:
THaÌ arthur & gouernar toke their horses & rode to the straÌge in the forest where as they founde Iehannet & her moder, who made great Ioy & feest and IehaÌnet behelde arthur who was as than right pale for dyspleasure & demauÌded of him what was the cause of his displeasure. Certaynly my loue said arthur greater displeasure coulde neuer haue fallen. For my lorde my father wil now mary me the which I forthinke wt al mi herte because of the loue yt I haue to you for I thinke veryly ye wyl not be conteÌt therwt. And your displeasure perseth myn herte. A min owne swete lord sayd IehaÌnet for gods sake trouble not your selfe for no cause for in certayne I am in like case fallen in a treatie to be maried. A good loue sayd Arthur I prai you to whome. Syr so god helpe me to him of whome I haue spoken to you of here before is yt of a trouth faire damoisel quod arthur and I requyre you whaÌ shal ye be maried, in trouth the same propre day that ye shal maryed, now fayre damoysel by the faith the ye o â¢ e to hiÌ I desyre you let me se hiÌ syr ye may not se
hym as yet, but for certayne he shall be aperayled in ye same clothyng & sute as ye shall be the day of your wedding. In the name of god sayd arthur I haue of this great meruayle for ye haue sayde here before to me that he is as great of lignage as I am and as gretly endued wyth hauyour and frendes â¢ and how y â¢ he resembleth to me in all pointes, and also howe that he hath a ryche & a puissaunt vncle. I wote not whome I shold thinke without ye meane al this by my self, for I know wel the erle of Bloys is my vncle by my moders side. wel sir sayd IehaÌnet nor I wyll not shew you at this present time. So thus they commined together of â¢ hat and of other thiÌ ges tyll finally arthur tooke leue of her for that tyme and â¢ etourned to the courte of his father. And thus dayly he rode to se this fayre daymoysel Iehannet til it came to the next day before his wedding. And the erle of Aniou and the archebys â¢ hop of tours were come, and also the erle of Blois who brought with him Hector his son who was a gentill and a fayre creture & was â¢ xtr â¢ ught of the linage of brytayne, & was cosin germayn to arthur & also of one age for thei were borne bothe in one yeare. And as Arthur saw him he made him great ioy and feest, and al wayes kept companye togyder. And so there came f â¢ o al partes lordes knightes ladies & damoysels by g â¢ eat flockes for to go mete the ladi perron of ostryge. And than mounted the duke and al other barons & knightes â¢ o go lykewyse to encountre Perron. who was as than come within the space of halfe a lege & brought wi â¢ h her a great coÌpany of lordes knightes, ladies and damoysels.

div.head: Â¶How that Arthur & Hector his cosyn germayne were made knightes for the loue of Arthur, who thaÌ did ensure Perron doughter to ye lady Luke of ostrige. And of the great tornay that was there done at nauntes for the loue of arthur Cap. x.
div.p:
ANd whan all these noble people were ass â¢ bled together the duke and duch â¢ sse and all other lordes made great ioye & feest at the metynge of thys lady Luke and Perron her doughter. And the duchesse toke her in her armes, and sayd a myne owne swete doughter ye be into this countrey right welcome and kissed her oft â¢ ntim â¢ s wepyng for Ioye For she was so fayre a creature yt the duchesse coulde not absteyne her self fro clypping & kissing her. And therewt called to her arthur & sayd fayre sone arthur beholde here this fayre lady who is & shall be yours. Madame sayd arthur wyll it please you to suffre her to mouÌt vpon her horse & we shal speke of thys matter well ynoughe here after. So they went all to horse and rode forth to nauntes. And there lordes, knightes & other toke vp theyr lodginge in the citie and some were harboured in the palais with the duke. And whan it came to the tyme to speke of the maryage than arthur sayde in open audyence. My lorde my father, and also my ladye my mothe â¢ ye wyll cause me here to take this damoysell. And yet I knowe not what name or fame that she is of. How be it syr I say surely b â¢ the to you & also to you my Lady Luke who is mother vnto her that I take her agaynste my herte bycause of the suspeccyons, noise and yll renowmes the whyche that I haue harde saye and reported of her.
Neuerthelesse it behoueth me to take her to exchewe therby the displeasure of my lorde my fader, & of my lady my moder & other of my frendes for I perceiue wel it is theyr mindes. How be it I say openly here to you all yf yt I finde such noyse as renneth on her to be of trouth I ensure you yt whyle I lyue she shal neuer haue one good day with me in rest. A my fayre sone sayd the duchesse what & ye finde her good & true. And that all such ill noyse as ye haue harde of her be vntrew and false. Well madame sayde arthur â¢ han shal I loue her as I ought to do my wyfe. Than the duke called forth the archebysshop of nauntes and so caused arthur to be there openly fiauÌ ced to Perron and on the next day to be maryed. ThaÌ began great feest and ioy in the palays. And dauÌsyng of ladies & damoyselles, & frusshyng of speres & bateryng of harneys wt swerdes in euerye strete of the citie. Than the duke â¢ ayde that who so euer wolde take the ordre of chiual â¢ y wt his son Arthur the nexte daye with a good wyll he wolde gyue them the ordre. ThaÌ arthur sayd to hector his cosyn syr I requyre you to morow take the ordre of knighthode with me & fro hensforth let vs kepe coÌpanye togider in iustes & tornay â¢ & in al other thinges as sworne bretherne. Fayre cosin sayd Hector I requyre you let vs go know the pleasure of my lord my father whither that he wil agre to this or not. â¢ e say well sayd arthur. Than arthur â¢â¢ before the duke his fader and al other lordes & helde his cosyn Hector by the haÌd & sayd openly to the erle of Bloys, m â¢ lorde my vncle I requyre you my let cosyn hector be made knight to morow wt me for we shal loue togider the be â¢ ter euer after certaynly sayd the erle fayre neuew, hector hath as yet to lytle londe to susteyne therwyth the noble ordre of knighthode. And yt he sayde bycause he wold not yt is sone shold be made knight so sone. Truly syr said arthur he hath richesse inough to be a knight for as loge as ye lyue he can not fayle. And though he fayle of you y â¢ t god hath so prouided for him yt after your dayes he shal be erle of Blois. Ye fayre neuew ê the erle we may both be disceiued by that, for it may â¢ o fortune that I may lese all my right in the erledome of bloys & his also. Nor let not my sone He â¢ tor â¢ oke to be lord ouer me for as loÌge as I liue one fote of the londe of the e â¢ ledom of bloys geteth he not, no syr saide arthur & tou â¢ ned to hector and said fayre cosin it s â¢ old seme wel by the saying of my lorde your fader how that he is very pore. How be it I desi â¢ e you to be kni â¢ t wt me & I faithfullie promise you ye I shall giue you as much loÌde or more as my lorde your fader wil giue you â¢ an â¢ I pray you fro heÌsforth let vs be togider as c â¢ panions â¢ n horse, in abilimeÌtes, in laÌde, in house & in euery thinge. And so I retayne you fro this preseÌt time forth â¢ ard. As god help me fayre so sayd the duke. Who had hard what arthur had sayd to Hector I am wel coÌ
â¢ ent that ye thus retaine Hector your cosin. Also I r â¢ quyre him that he wil be your coÌpanion. and to the erle of Bloys he said â¢ Also syr I desyre you to giue licence to your son Hector that he may be knight with his cosin Arthur. ThaÌ the e â¢ le of Bloys dyd laughe therat and sayd to the duke. Syr as god me helme I am ryght wel conteÌte. But â¢ f one thing let him be sure that as longe as I liue he shall neuer be the Erle of Bloys. Than arthur sayde to hys cosyn Hector. well syr we be yonge ynoughe.
therfore we shall seke to get our lyuing for I trust god shal help vs. Than he sayd to the duke his father syr gouernar hath serued & norisshed me vp swetelye, therfore I requyre you let me make him knight and whan I may I wyl do better to hym, certaynly fayre sonne it pleaseth me right well. So than they were made knightes with great tryumpheâª & there was made great Ioye & fest both with lordes and ladies, and a great tornay was there ordeyned for the loue of these new knightes. And whyle this triumphe and tornay endured Arthur sayd to h â¢ ctor. Fayre cosyn come on with me & we wil go se the most swete and gentyl damoysel yt euer ye saw. In the name of god ê h â¢ ctor I am well content And so art â¢ ur, hector & gouernar mounted on theyr horses and rode forth to the manoyr of the staÌge where as they fouÌd IehaÌn â¢ t and her moder lening in a wyndow talkyng togyder, & whan they saw arthur they came to hym & made gr â¢ at ioye â¢ And than â¢ ehaÌnet demaunded of Arthur, syr quod she what gentyl man is this that ye haue brou â¢ ht with you. Fayre loue sayd Arthur he is sonne to the erle of bloys, and he is my cosyn germayne. In ye name of god sayd she he is h â¢ ther welcome for your sake. Than Iehann â¢ t behel â¢ e well Arthur and she p â¢ rceyu â¢ d b â¢ his couÌtenaunce yt he was tr â¢ ub â¢â¢ d, the â¢ fore she desyred of hym to know what he eylled in good faith god loue this day haue I made a dolorous Iorney for I haue fyaunc â¢ d a woman agaynst my wil, yt whiche I sore repeÌt bycause it is grefull to me to leue youre companye, ce â¢ tayne fayre loue Arthur quod she take no dyspleasure thoughe y â¢ it haue fiauÌced a lady for certaynlye in the same propre hou â¢ e that ye fyaunced your ladye I was fyaunced to my loue. And my dere loue quod Arthur I requyre you who is that and where is he. By the fayth ye I owe vnto you syr I knoweful wel where he is. wel fayre lady sayd arthur I pray you than shew him to me â¢ surely syr that â¢ yll I not do as yet but I promise you to shew hym to you within these thre dayes next commyng. And syr know you for certayne that he resembleth to you both in comynge in goinge, in hauioure, in frendes, gentylnes in facion of body and in al other thinges. â¢ n the name of god sayd Arthur â¢ meruayle g â¢ eatly for by your wordes it shold appere yt it were myself for there cannot two persons be resembled togider but theyr must be som faute & difference. I beleue ye deuise these wordes for me, how be it I am troubled agayne whaÌ I thinke how ye saye that ye were fiaunced to day, and how that ye shall be maryed to morowe the same propre houre that I shal be wedded in. As god helpe me syr sayd Iehannet it is of â¢ routh he resembl â¢ th to you wtout faylyng of any poynte, veryly sayde arthur I cannot thinke whome it should be. And so they talked together so longe til it was tyme for arthur to departe for he doubted to be blamed of hys fr â¢â¢ des. So he toke l â¢ ue of the ladyes and departed & as they rode hector sayd to arthur syr vndouted this is a fayre yonge lady right gracious, swete & fayre behauing as god help me fayre cosyn sayde arthur she is mine owne howe be it she is a poore damoysell nor hath no thynge but yt she hath of me. But by the faythe that I owe vnto my lord and father the duke of brytayne I loue her better al naked than she that I shal haue wtall the â¢ iches of the world, for I must take her
agenst my wyll. And therfore cosyn I am veryly purposed that as sone as th â¢ s tryumphe is passe â¢ , and all straungers be departed, and myne vncle youre fader and all gone, than I thynk â¢ to ask â¢ lyceÌ ce of m â¢ fader to go â¢ s â¢ ke aduentures in some straunge couÌtrees and to take with me alon â¢ lye Gouernar and to abyde f â¢ o hom â¢ the space of .v. or .vi. yeres. And so sh â¢ ll I leue her th â¢ t troubleth me, for in h â¢ r company in no wyse I can abyde. Truely syr sayd Hector and yf yt ye wyl thus god by the fayth that I owe to you I wyll d â¢ parte wyth you, and neuer to leue you whyle that I lyue. A good cosyn Hector qu â¢ d Arthur it pleaseth mee ver â¢ ly well to haue youre companye, and her â¢ ely I thanke you thereof. How be it I beseche you kepe this thyng secret that i â¢ be not knowen tyll the tyme of our departyng â¢ . And as soone as Arthur was â¢â¢ part â¢ d frome Iehannet, she dyd senne all aboute for mynstrelles and instrumeÌ tes of musyke. And caused a â¢ l the house to be hanged wyth sylke, and commaunded all her folkes to make as g â¢ eate Ioy and feest as they coude ymagen. And so this Arthur rod forth alwayes til he came to N â¢ unt â¢ s where as the tables were redy couered to souper. And the duke se â¢ to hym downe and all other lordes â¢ euery man in his place, and they were serued ryght rychely wyth gre â¢ e Ioye, and after souper they played and sported theÌ
â¢ uery m â¢ n as he b â¢ ste l â¢â¢ ed tyll it was se â¢ son to go to rest. For than it was past mydnighte. And so the duke than entred in â¢ o his chambre. And Arthur, Hector and Gouernar weÌt to se Iehannet, and whan they came nere to the place of the s â¢ ange they herde greate noyse & myrthe of instrumentes â¢ and â¢ ound all the house newly hanged. And the ladyes arayed wt vestures of pleasure. And they founde as grea â¢ e apparayle as thoughe a kyng sh â¢ lde haue come thyder. And Iehann â¢ t was apparayled as though she sh â¢â¢â¢ e haue be m â¢ ryed incoÌtyneÌt. And whaÌ she harde that Arthur was come thyder â¢â¢ e came goodly vn â¢ o him.
